dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, B, it's pretty amazing, right? Like, vaccines are actually rolling out. And fast!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, B, it's pretty amazing, right? Like, vaccines are actually rolling out. And fast!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The speed and scale at which vaccines are being provided is both extraordinary and necessary to end the pandemic, and is possible only thanks to an unprecedented show of global solidarity and multilateral support for COVAX, the central mechanism in the global COVID-19 vaccination effort, launched last year by the World Health Organization and Gavi, the Vaccine Alliance (which I led).

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely, A! And I mean, not just in rich countries, which is, uh, kinda what we expected. But also, slowly but surely, in lower-income nations too.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely, A! And I mean, not just in rich countries, which is, uh, kinda what we expected. But also, slowly but surely, in lower-income nations too.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Vaccines will reach the majority of rich-country citizens in the first quarter of this year, and citizens of low- and lower-middle-income countries will also begin to access them.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and that's largely thanks to something called COVAX, which, uh, the article really highlights as this extraordinary global effort. Like, two billion doses over the next year... that's a lot.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and that's largely thanks to something called C O V A X, which, uh, the article really highlights as this extraordinary global effort. Like, two billion doses over the next year... that's a lot.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: COVAX will facilitate the rollout of two billion vaccine doses over the next year, reaching people in 190 participating countries and economies, regardless of their ability to pay.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and the key part is it's for 190 countries, [interrupts] regardless of whether they can actually pay for them.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and the key part is it's for one hundred ninety countries, regardless of whether they can actually pay for them.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: COVAX will facilitate the rollout of two billion vaccine doses over the next year, reaching people in 190 participating countries and economies, regardless of their ability to pay.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. That's a huge deal. But, you know, it's not all smooth sailing. The article talks about this idea of 'vaccine nationalism'.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. That's a huge deal. But, you know, it's not all smooth sailing. The article talks about this idea of vaccine nationalism.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Vaccine nationalism is precisely the problem that COVAX was created to solve.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, definitely. It's like, every country wants to protect its own first, which is understandable, but then you get these bilateral deals, and um, suddenly you have rich countries buying way more doses than they even need.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, definitely. It's like, every country wants to protect its own first, which is understandable, but then you get these bilateral deals, and um, suddenly you have rich countries buying way more doses than they even need.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Unfortunately, we are already seeing some governments buy far more doses than they need, adding to the pressure on global supply during this critical initial phase.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right. And then, like, you're back to that H1N1 situation in 2009 where only a few rich countries got the vaccine, and everyone else was just out of luck. We *cannot* repeat that.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right. And then, like, you're back to that H one N one situation in two thousand nine where only a few rich countries got the vaccine, and everyone else was just out of luck. We cannot repeat that.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In tackling COVID-19, we must avoid a repeat of 2009, when a small number of rich countries bought up most of global supply of H1N1 flu vaccine, leaving the rest of the world with none.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! I mean, if we don't vaccinate everyone, everywhere, the virus just keeps circulating. It's not going to end the pandemic for *anyone* if it's still spreading elsewhere.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! I mean, if we don't vaccinate everyone, everywhere, the virus just keeps circulating. It's not going to end the pandemic for anyone if it's still spreading elsewhere.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: To end the cycle, we cannot vaccinate only some people in some countries; we must protect all people everywhere.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: And COVAX is trying to be flexible, but it really needs manufacturers to give them the same access as national governments. Otherwise, uh, it's just harder.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And C O V A X is trying to be flexible, but it really needs manufacturers to give them the same access as national governments. Otherwise, uh, it's just harder.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Although COVAX is flexible enough to work around this particular problem, it can do so only as long as manufacturers provide it with the same access to vaccines as national governments receive.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and what about those countries that *have* bought too many doses? The article says they should, like, donate their surplus through the Gavi/COVAX Advance Market Commitment.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and what about those countries that have bought too many doses? The article says they should, like, donate their surplus through the Gavi C O V A X Advance Market Commitment.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The best way to ensure that they are is for donor governments to go through the Gavi/COVAX Advance Market Commitment (AMC) mechanism, which was created to ensure that COVID-19 vaccines are made available to people living in the worlds 92 low- and middle-income countries.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely. I mean, COVAX has already secured about a billion doses for 92 lower-income countries, which is, uh, pretty incredible progress if you think about it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely. I mean, C O V A X has already secured about a billion doses for ninety two lower-income countries, which is, uh, pretty incredible progress if you think about it.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: So far, COVAX has secured around one billion doses for people in these countries, by striking deals with manufacturers of several of the most-promising vaccine candidates.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: It is, but they need more. More doses, more manufacturers stepping up to make them affordable, and just, like, more funding. The US actually stepped up with four billion, which is great.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It is, but they need more. More doses, more manufacturers stepping up to make them affordable, and just, like, more funding. The U S actually stepped up with four billion, which is great.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But many more doses are needed. All manufacturers must step up and make their vaccines available and affordable to COVAX, so that there can be a timely global rollout... and in December, the United States allocated $4 billion for Gavi in its second COVID-19 relief package.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: It really is. It shows that, um, despite all the challenges and the naysayers, the global community *can* rally. We're at this critical juncture now, and the article says we need to stop speculating about failure and just ensure it succeeds.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It really is. It shows that, um, despite all the challenges and the naysayers, the global community can rally. We're at this critical juncture now, and the article says we need to stop speculating about failure and just ensure it succeeds.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Now that we have reached this critical juncture, speculation about whether COVAX will fail must stop. It is time to start providing the support needed to ensure that it succeeds in doing what it was designed to do.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. It's the only viable global solution, you know? It just needs that continued support to finish the job.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. It's the only viable global solution, you know? It just needs that continued support to finish the job.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: These participants are signing on because they recognize that COVAX is the only viable global solution to the COVID-19 crisis... All COVAX needs now is enough international support to finish the job.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Couldn't agree more, B. Global solidarity. It's the key.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Couldn't agree more, B. Global solidarity. It's the key.
